Since its identification in January 2020 to the time of writing, SARS-CoV-2 has caused coronavirus disease (COVID-19) in almost 10 million people worldwide and resulted in 500,000 deaths.
1 However, COVID-19 morbidity and mortality exhibits significant variation across age groups. Early publications revealed SARS-CoV-2 could cause a wide spectrum of illness in adults, and children were seemingly under-represented with regard to both the total number of cases as well as the likelihood of experiencing severe disease.
2
,
3 Comprehensive population-based epidemiological studies have confirmed this finding, revealing a lower prevalence of SARS-CoV-2 infection in children compared to adults. 4, 5, 6 Furthermore, if children do acquire SARS-CoV-2, the vast majority experience mild disease not requiring hospitalisation,
